sen.j: 柳沢氏（やなぎさわし）は、日本の氏族（武士）。
sen.e: The Yanagisawas were a Japanese feudal clan (Samurai warriors).
The Yanagisawas were a Japanese feudal clan (samurai warriors).
The Yanagisawa was a Japanese feudal clan (samurai warriors).
sen.cmt: Yanagisawas wereをYanagisawa wasに変更しました。

sen.j: 清和源氏源義光流武田氏（甲斐源氏）の一族。
sen.e: It was part of the Takeda clan (Kai genji), which belonged to the Yoshimitsu MINAMOTO's branch, a Seiwa Genji (Minamoto clan).
They were part of the Takeda clan (Kai genji), which belonged to the Yoshimitsu MINAMOTO's branch, a Seiwa Genji (Minamoto clan).
They were part of the Takeda clan (Kai genji), which belonged to the Yoshimitsu MINAMOTO's branch, a Seiwa Genji (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: 江戸時代の譜代大名。
sen.e: They were fudai daimyo (retainers who supported the Tokugawa shogunate) during the Edo period.
They were fudai daimyo (retainers who supported the Tokugawa shogunate) during the Edo period.
They were fudai daimyo (retainers who supported the Tokugawa shogunate) during the Edo period.

sen.j: 家紋は柳沢花菱。
sen.e: The family crest is Yanagisawa Hanabishi.
The family crest is Yanagisawa Hanabishi.
The family crest is Yanagisawa Hanabishi.

sen.j: 柳沢氏が甲斐源氏の一族である甲斐一条氏の子孫が甲斐国北西部の武川筋に土着した武川衆と呼ばれる辺境武士団であった。
sen.e: Yanagisawa clan is a descendent of the Kai Ichijo clan belonging to the Kai-Genji (Minamoto clan), and became part of the Mukawa-shu group, one of the warrior groups in remote Kai area based in Mukawa in the northwestern part of the Kai Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: The Yanagisawa clan descended from the Kai Ichijo clan belonging to the Kai-Genji (Minamoto clan) and became part of the Mukawa-shu group, one of the warrior groups in the remote Kai area based in Mukawa, in the northwestern part of Kai Province.

The Yanagisawa clan descended from the Kai Ichijo clan belonging to the Kai-Genji (Minamoto clan) and became part of the Mukawa-shu group, one of the warrior groups in the remote Kai area based in Mukawa, in the northwestern part of Kai Province.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には甲斐守護武田氏の家臣となる。
sen.e: During the Sengoku Period (period of warring states in Japan), they became retainers of the Takeda clan, who held the post of the military governor of Kai area.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: During the Sengoku (Warring States) period of Japan, they became retainers of the Takeda clan, who held the post of military governor in the Kai area.
During the Sengoku (Warring States) period of Japan, they became retainers of the Takeda clan, who held the post of military governor in the Kai area.

sen.j: 武田氏滅亡後は武田遺臣として徳川家康に仕える。
sen.e: After the fall of the Takeda clan, the members of the clan served under Ieyasu TOKUGAWA as the surviving retainers of the Takeda clan.
After the fall of the Takeda clan, the members of the clan served under Ieyasu TOKUGAWA as the surviving retainers of the Takeda clan.
After the fall of the Takeda clan, the members of the clan served under Ieyasu TOKUGAWA as the surviving retainers of the Takeda clan.

sen.j: 柳沢安忠のときに駿河国大納言徳川忠長（徳川秀忠の子）の家臣となったが、忠長が兄徳川家光によって蟄居・幽閉に処せられたため浪人になった。
sen.e: Yasutada YANAGISAWA became a retainer of Dainagon (chief councilor of state) Tadanaga TOKUGAWA (a son of Hidetada TOKUGAWA) of Suruga Province, but when Tadanaga was put under house-arrest by his elder brother Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, Yasutada became a warrior without a lord.

Yasutada YANAGISAWA became a retainer of the Dainagon (chief councilor of state) Tadanaga TOKUGAWA (a son of Hidetada TOKUGAWA) of Suruga Province, but when Tadanaga was placed under house arrest by his elder brother Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, Yasutada became a warrior without a lord.

Yasutada YANAGISAWA became a retainer of the Dainagon (chief councilor of state) Tadanaga TOKUGAWA (a son of Hidetada TOKUGAWA) of Suruga Province, but when Tadanaga was placed under house arrest by his elder brother Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, Yasutada became a warrior without a lord.

sen.j: その後、安忠は上野国館林藩主（現在の群馬県館林市）徳川綱吉に仕えて勘定頭を務めた。
sen.e: Yasutada later became a retainer of Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA, who was the lord of Tatebayashi, Kozuke no kuni Province (currently Tatebayashi, Gunma Prefecture) and became kanjo gashira (chief treasurer).

Yasutada later became a retainer of Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA, who was the lord of Tatebayashi, Kozuke no kuni Province (the present-day Tatebayashi, Gunma Prefecture) and became kanjo gashira (chief treasurer).

Yasutada later became a retainer of Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA, who was the lord of Tatebayashi, Kozuke no kuni Province (the present-day Tatebayashi City, Gunma Prefecture) and became kanjo gashira (chief treasurer).
sen.cmt: Tatebayashiの後にCityを挿入しました。

sen.j: 安忠の子柳沢吉保は綱吉の腹心となり、綱吉が5代将軍になると元禄元年（1688年）1万石を与えられて側用人になり、松平姓を許された。
sen.e: Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA, the son of Yasutada, became a confidant of Tsunayoshi, and when Tsunayoshi became the fifth Shogun, Yoshiyasu was given 10,000 koku, became a goyonin (one of the most senior retainers of shogun) and was allowed to use the name of MATSUDAIRA.

Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA, the son of Yasutada, became a confidant of Tsunayoshi, and when Tsunayoshi became the fifth shogun, Yoshiyasu was given 10,000 koku, became a goyonin (one of the most senior retainers of the shogun) and was allowed to use the name MATSUDAIRA.

Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA, the son of Yasutada, became a confidant of Tsunayoshi, and when Tsunayoshi became the fifth shogun, Yoshiyasu was given 10,000 koku, became a goyonin (one of the most senior retainers of the shogun) and was allowed to use the name MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 宝永元年（1704年）甲府城主15万1200石となり、甲府藩主となる。
sen.e: In 1704, he became the lord of Kofu-jo Castle with 151,200 koku and became lord of Kai.
In 1704, he became the lord of Kofu-jo Castle with 151,200 koku and also became the lord of Kai.
In 1704, he became the lord of Kofu-jo Castle with 151,200 koku and also became the lord of Kai.

sen.j: 吉保の子柳沢吉里の代で大和国郡山藩（奈良県大和郡山市）に転封され、彼の家系は15万石の大名として幕末まで至った。
sen.e: During the time of Yoshisato YANAGISAWA, the son of Yoshiyasu, the governing land of the clan was switched to Koriyama domain, Yamato Province (currently Yamato Koriyama City, Nara Prefecture), and his family continued to be a daimyo with 150,000 koku until the end of bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

During the time of Yoshisato YANAGISAWA, the son of Yoshiyasu, the governing land of the clan was switched to the Koriyama Domain, Yamato Province (currently Yamato Koriyama City, Nara Prefecture), and his family continued to be a daimyo with 150,000 koku until the end of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

During the time of Yoshisato YANAGISAWA, the son of Yoshiyasu, the governing land of the clan was switched to the Koriyama Domain, Yamato Province (currently Yamato Koriyama City, Nara Prefecture), and his family continued to be a daimyo with 150,000 koku until the end of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 歴代当主は美濃国守あるいは甲斐守に任ぜられた。
sen.e: The head of the clan was traditionally named as either the lord of Mino Province or of Kai Province.
The head of the clan was traditionally designated as the lord of either Mino Province or Kai Province.
The head of the clan was traditionally designated as the lord of either Mino Province or Kai Province.

sen.j: 明治時代に華族に列し、明治17年（1884年）柳沢保申が伯爵になった。
sen.e: They became a peer during the Meiji period, and in 1884, Yasunobu YANAGISAWA became a count.
They attained peerage during the Meiji period, and in 1884 Yasunobu YANAGISAWA became a count.
They attained peerage during the Meiji period, and in 1884 Yasunobu YANAGISAWA became a count.

sen.j: 武田氏宗家の高家武田氏とは密接な関係にあり、保申の次男、武田信保が高家武田氏の当主を継ぎ、血筋が絶えることなく現在に至っている。
sen.e: The YANAGISAWA clan has a close relationship with Koke Takeda clan, the main stream of the Takeda clan, and Nobuyasu TAKEDA, the second son of Yasunobu, became the head of Koke Takeda clan and the blood line continues to this day.

The YANAGISAWA clan had a close relationship with the Koke Takeda clan, the main stream of the Takeda clan; Nobuyasu TAKEDA, the second son of Yasunobu, became the head of Koke Takeda clan, and the bloodline continues today.

The YANAGISAWA clan had a close relationship with the Koke Takeda clan, the main stream of the Takeda clan; Nobuyasu TAKEDA, the second son of Yasunobu, became the head of Koke Takeda clan, and the bloodline continues today.

sen.j: 吉保の4男柳沢経隆は宝永6年（1709年）甲斐国八代郡（現在の山梨市・甲州市）に甲府新田藩1万石を与えられ、享保9年（1724年）越後国蒲原郡黒川（新潟県蒲原郡黒川村 (新潟県北蒲原郡)・現在の新潟県胎内市黒川）で黒川藩1万石の大名になり、幕末まで続いた。
sen.e: Tsunetaka YANAGISAWA, the fourth son of Yoshiyasu, was bestowed the Kai Nitta domain with 10,000 koku in the Yashiro gun, Kai Province, (currently Yamanashi and Kofu cities) in 1709, then in 1724 became the daimyo of Kurokawa domain with 10,000 koku in Kurokawa, Kanbara-gun, Echigo Province (which became Kurokawa town, Kanbara gun, Niigata Prefecture (Kita Kanbara-gun, Niigata Prefecture), and is currently Kurokawa Tainai-shi City, Niigata Prefecture) and the descendents continued to retain the post until the end of bakufu.

Tsunetaka YANAGISAWA, the fourth son of Yoshiyasu, was bestowed the Kai Nitta Domain with 10,000 koku in Yashiro gun, Kai Province (the present-day cities of Yamanashi and Kofu) in 1709, then in 1724 became the daimyo of the Kurokawa Domain with 10,000 koku in Kurokawa, Kanbara-gun, Echigo Province (which became Kurokawa Town, Kanbara gun, Niigata Prefecture (Kita Kanbara-gun, Niigata Prefecture) and is currently Kurokawa Tainai-shi City, Niigata Prefecture) and the descendents continued to hold that post until the end of the bakufu.

Tsunetaka YANAGISAWA, the fourth son of Yoshiyasu, was bestowed the Kai Nitta Domain with 10,000 koku in Yashiro gun, Kai Province (the present-day cities of Yamanashi and Kofu) in 1709, then in 1724 became the daimyo of the Kurokawa Domain with 10,000 koku in Kurokawa, Kanbara-gun, Echigo Province (which became Kurokawa Town, Kanbara gun, Niigata Prefecture (Kita Kanbara-gun, Niigata Prefecture) and is currently Kurokawa Tainai-shi City, Niigata Prefecture) and the descendents continued to hold that post until the end of the bakufu.

sen.j: 明治17年（1884年）柳沢光邦が子爵になった。
sen.e: In 1884, Mitsukuni YANAGISAWA became a viscount.
In 1884, Mitsukuni YANAGISAWA became a viscount.
In 1884, Mitsukuni YANAGISAWA became a viscount.

sen.j: また吉保の5男柳沢時睦も享保9年蒲原郡内（新潟県新発田市北部・北蒲原郡加治川村西部）において1万石を与えられて三日市藩主となった。
sen.e: Tokichika YANAGISAWA, the fifth son of Yoshiyasu, was given 10,000 koku in Kanbara-gun (currently in the northern part of Shibata City and the western part of Kajikawa village, Kita Kanbara gun, Niigata Prefecture) in 1724 and became the lord of Mikkaichi City.

Tokichika YANAGISAWA, the fifth son of Yoshiyasu, was given 10,000 koku in Kanbara-gun (currently in the northern part of Shibata City and the western part of Kajikawa village, Kita Kanbara gun, Niigata Prefecture) in 1724, and became the lord of Mikkaichi City.

Tokichika YANAGISAWA, the fifth son of Yoshiyasu, was given 10,000 koku in Kanbara-gun (currently in the northern part of Shibata City and the western part of Kajikawa village, Kita Kanbara gun, Niigata Prefecture) in 1724, and became the lord of Mikkaichi City.

sen.j: その後、上館（新発田市）に陣屋を移して幕末に至った。
sen.e: Later, the family moved to Kamitate (Shibata City) where they remained until the end of bakufu.
Later, the family moved to Kamitate (Shibata City) and remained until the end of the bakufu.
Later, the family moved to Kamitate (Shibata City) and remained until the end of the bakufu.

sen.j: 明治17年（1884年）に柳沢徳忠が子爵になった。
sen.e: In 1884, Noritada YANAGISAWA became a viscount.
In 1884, Noritada YANAGISAWA became a viscount.
In 1884, Noritada YANAGISAWA became a viscount.
